DOC.HEAD: China Names New Chief of Planning
DOC.TEXT: Vice Premier Yao Yilin, an economic expert who helped steer China back toward more central planning, was replaced as head of the powerful State Planning Commission by technocrat Zou Jiahua, it was announced Tuesday. Zou, who headed the Machine Building and Electronics Industry, was appointed by the National People's Congress, China's parliament. The official Xinhua News Agency quoted Premier Li Peng as telling parliament that Yao was being asked to step down so he could concentrate on helping Li with the work of the State Council, or cabinet. The move did not immediately appear to signify that Yao was in disfavor. It may be designed to groom Zou, a rising star who has been mentioned as a future member of the Politburo. Yao, 72, moved into prominence the past year with his economic policies committing China to a lengthy period of austerity, restoring state controls over many aspects of the economy and halting market-oriented economic reforms. He has worked closely with Li, another economic conservative who has sought to reverse the fast pace of economic reforms favored by ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang. Yao is one of the six members of the party's decision-making Politburo Standing Committee, as is Li. The full Politburo, previously composed of 17 members, is now down to 14 after the death in April of former party chief Hu Yaobang and the ouster of moderates Zhao and Hu Qili in June following the military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. Zou, 63, like Li, studied in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and has a background in heavy industry. He has close connections with China's military through previous offices.
